utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Lawrence Jones, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, this is "The Five." Let's get after it. All right, the war of words hits a whole new level as President Trump unleashes on the media in one of his fiercest attacks yet. The president slamming much of that press on Twitter today as, quote, totally dishonest, who says -- he says don't care for the truth, writing fake books and using anonymous sources that are pure fiction. This comes after Trump blasted CNN and veteran journalist Carl Bernstein over the network's Trump Tower report, the president saying that the network has been caught in a major lie. CNN and Bernstein firing back at the president saying they stand by their reporting. Greg, lots of tweets overnight.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Lots of tweets. I'm glad he was tweeting about this and not about the funeral. But Trump is like a heckler behind the dugout. He senses -- he can sense the central weakness of the pitcher. In this case, the pitcher is CNN. And he won't stop until the guy throws the mitt down and runs to the stands to fight and he's getting that. And what he's doing is he's giving CNN the CNN treatment because they made that meeting story into a relentless bombshell. Every newscaster was having a conniption about it. And now that story seems to be falling apart and Trump is giving CNN the relentless falling-apart story and he won't let go. So now, I think it's even Stevens and blast point. Whenever I get like a little bit upset or annoyed about the tweeting, I remember that the media spent decades punching at conservatives, for decades, probably since the Vietnam War. Now, somebody is punching back and they're crying foul. So, I -- it's hard for me to sympathize with the media when they're complaining since they in the left have been, essentially, interchangeable since Vietnam. We're going to need a lot of Trump tweets to kind of even the score, I think.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Wow. You know what I think.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There might be a lot where that came from, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know -- first of all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You like that, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't. I mean, even if I was on the right, I would say, oh, so Rush Limbaugh to William F. Buckley didn't exist? There's no conservative thought expressed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nothing like this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, not like.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, coming at you like -- I mean, obviously, twitter is a new vehicle so that's different.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But I think -- I mean, to me, what was incredible was in the middle of a funeral for a statesman, John McCain, what's our president doing? He's not saying, oh, you know, my thoughts, my prayers -- no, no, he's attacking CNN. He's so obsessed with them that right in the middle of a funeral.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: They're obsessed with him, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't like this because it's not only the story, Lawrence. Because the story.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: A lie?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, he tells a lot -- I mean.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: This has been the media narrative that they are there to hold the president accountable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They should be.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Part of the reason why they're losing credibility with the American people with their approval rating is lower than congress is because they don't tell the truth sometimes. It's a simple fix. Tell the American people, hey, we've mess up on this. We issue a retraction.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're not doing that, Emily, because CNN says there's standing by their story.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . and I imagine that this -- have gone into journalism school, that that's because they say they have another source. It might not be true, but I don't imagine that they're totally lying about this.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, THE FIVE CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, my biggest issue with this is the fact that -- of course the president can take issue with any organization that he thinks is skewing coverage of him. That has called his a malignant administration, whatever. But I think at a certain point, it's beneath the office of the presidency. And to me, like everything, it's distracting. And when this becomes the story then it's totally detracting from what's really is the story to me, which is the fact that this large-scale investigation has been undertaken right now with our tax dollars, and it's either pursuing nefarious conduct or furthering nefarious conduct. And we have a ton of unanswered questions about intelligence gathering, protocol, and breaks in chain of command, and the interplay between the DOJ and FBI and congress and this administration and whether uncorroborated, unverified information is being relied upon by law enforcement and potentially the courts and then being leaked tactically by officials in the government that are rogue. So, to me, these are all the larger questions. And when the story becomes the social media warfare or media warfare, it just does everyone a disservice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that's all a great conspiracy theory because I think if you're going to say that so many judges, the FBI run by a Republican, the Department of Justice run by them. But here's the thing to me. He's going on about alternative facts, fake news. Oh, gee, I wonder what the FBI had to say this week when he picked up on some conservatives, you know, report. Oh, Hillary Clinton's emails were hacked by the Chinese. The FBI comes out -- I mean, I guess it's some political risk for themselves given this presidents antics and says no, there's no evidence that Hillary Clinton's emails were ever hacked. And then he goes on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: By the Chinese.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the Chinese.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But he didn't go to journalism school.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, let me just finish. Then he goes after Lester Holt on the old.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: God forbid, Lester Holt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And what he said is, oh, Lester Holt fudge that. This is the first time we've ever heard that there's any -- so exactly who has the trouble telling the truth? I think it's not NBC, not CNN, I think it's one guy named Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But, Juan, I think most of America understands that Trump plays fast and loose with the facts. But he's generally directionally right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: What politician does that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They all exaggerate every single detail. The question is, though, is it the media's job to be doing this? I mean, CNN literally calls him a racist every single night. And so, what is the president -- and they do this at every Republican (INAUDIBLE). The difference with Donald Trump is that he responds and his base loves it. There are sometimes I would agree that the president gets off-base with his tweets. I think we can all agree with that. But in large when it comes to the media, it's a winning issue for the president. That's why he continues to fight them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know that it's a winning issue. We'll see. But, I mean, to me, it's like he's just -- is a snowflake president. He's got a grievance and he can't get beyond.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I hope he's watching right now. I feel a tweet coming at you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? Greg, I want to give him a safe space.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have this prediction, 1970's will be -- known for disco. The '80s was known for like Betamax.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Reagan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or Reagan or big hair. The 90s was grunge. I think the teens, which is what this is, will be known for Trump's tweets. This is the thing that everybody looks back at as the thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The decade of twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And everybody will be laughing about it because it will be something that either came and went or established the whole.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I ask you something about -- on your podcast yesterday, you interviewed -- his name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jerry Eisenberg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Eisenberg. And one of the things -- this is a great podcast, by the way. He created -- he did all the creations for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He did the Jetsons, Flintstones, Scooby Doo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And one of the things he said that he loved the most is working on the Flintstones because -- I'm sorry, the Jetsons because he could use his imagination. And basically he invented Skype.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or face time. But he didn't invent twitter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he didn't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, that is the one thing that nobody saw coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I did. No, no, when I was in second grade, I used to write on the bathroom wall, anonymous stuff about people in my class. That's twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That is also another point of this. He is -- the president is complaining about anonymous sources, which every president complains about, but every White House asks to be quoted on background for certain things. He talks about a fake book. I imagine that could be Bob Woodward's book that is coming out September 11.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Do you think that's why he's attacking Bernstein?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . fire or fury. I don't know. But also, remember, he also used to be his own anonymous source here in New York City.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know, that was great.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: But I think -- oh, sorry. I feel like he's partly -- this is why he's used to it. He's used to driving the narrative and asking these questions. And I don't understand why he is expected -- again, I think there's a certain amount of decorum associated with the office that we'd like him to hold, but I don't understand why challenging the coverage and challenging these questions means that he should have a target on him for doing so, and regardless of the message. Because I do think it's important to ask those questions and for him to say, look, why aren't you covering this or cover this fairly? Or why am I not getting the benefit of the doubt when X has happened and Y.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, he said also -- like, twitter is a great tool for him. And one of the things he could have tweeted today was, check this out, 51 percent of workers in America say they are happy. That's the first time and.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . happen in years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why doesn't he do that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why doesn't he do that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because it's not him. You know what it is? Trump was radicalized by something, OK. Because he was a Democrat for a long time. He was fairly -- he was pro-choice, liberal and many things. He was radicalized. What was he radicalized by? Us, Fox News. Fox News -- when Fox News happened.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You started watching Fox News.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the world starts to make sense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sense to him. And then -- so all he's doing, Juan, is what we do, which is we bash the media. So he's just doing -- he's turned the White House into kind of like an alternative Fox show where he sits there and he.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought you're trying to help him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I'm actually saying it's kind of refreshing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kind of refreshing? You know what it reminds me of?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know Chuck Todd at NBC said? It's like one of those old guys going down the sidewalk mumbling to himself, except he has a million- plus twitter followers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're just jealous of his hair.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, I'll give you the last word.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that part of this is that the president once had a great relationship with the media as well.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And they turned on him. All the way into the primaries, they all wanted him to win. And now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They wanted him to do interviews.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And everyone was screaming to cover him, everybody wants the latest interview, and then they flipped on him. And so, I think the president is also ticked off about this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, indeed. All right, President Trump's team just took out one of the most dangerous terrorists since Bin Laden, but few noticed. Greg has the details, next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: While the media feasts on crocked lawyers and porn stars, one story slips by. According to the U.N., Al Qaeda's chief bomb maker was killed during a U.S. drone strike late last year. Ibrahim Hassan al-Asiri is his name. If this is the first you've heard of this, it's because, to the media, tax returns are more important than terror. The true irony, the Trump administration has been so good at killing terrorists that the media can focus that much more on hating the Trump administration. But this progress shouldn't be much comfort. What was al-Asiri known for? The marriage of technology and terror. He was the Thomas Edison of mayhem. Bombs hidden in printer cartridges and electronics that could sneak by scanners and dogs, non-metallic suicide vest, underwear bombs -- remember those? He didn't just design them, he also trained other designers who are still alive and ticking. Meaning Al Qaeda and ISIS are still coming for you and me, but that pales in comparison to a porn star payoff. For the longest time we've heard about climate change but terror change matters more. Even when terrorists fail, they evolve, even if their goal is to return us to the seventh century. That will always be the next really big headline. So we should be thankful for the intel that we get from our allies and our national security folks who remain vigilant while we call each other racists and complained about tweets. Lucky for us, these are great people who aren't distracted by thousands of hacks who give us poop and call it a scoop. You know, Dana, I like to rhyme, especially if I can include the word poop.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Can I compliment another line though?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Still alive and ticking?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very good line.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The problem with complacency -- the problem with success is complacency. And we've talked about this, prior to 9/11, we were talking about Chandra Levy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Remember that story?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Shark week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Shark week, that's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, I just know of a story, on September 10th, 2001, the White House communications team stayed late at the White House, so about 10 PM working on this big problem because the New York Times is going to have a front-page story the next day and it was going to be a doozy. It was going to be bad. It was going to make your whole week terrible. And it was the Dick Cheney energy task force.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did anybody remember that story? The big scandal because he allowed something who'd actually worked in the energy industry to brief him on energy policy, 9/11 happens the next morning and you never talked about the Dick Cheney energy task force again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . because it was important. I mean, we are living in good times, and that's what happens. Your point about the intel community, one of the most important things that we can ask of them is to be vigilant, but also to have wild imaginations. Like, imagine, what is the craziest thing and the meanest, the most evil thing that these terrorists would want to do to us, and that's what we have to prepare for.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's why Hollywood helps because they come up with great plotlines. I remember, New York Times, 9/11 that day, you know who their guest columnist was? Bill Ayers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't that crazy? A little piece of trivia there. All right. Lawrence, you're libertarian.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you think I'm to -- do I have too much terror on my mind or do you think -- there could never be enough vigilance?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No, I actually believe in a strong national defense. I just believe that every government agency likes to waste and abuse their money, and I don't think the military is exempt from that. One thing I will say about the president. Part of the reason why we don't hear about the military so much even though he has, you know, so much respect for our generals, is that he said he didn't want to talk about his military strategy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it's true.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And he made that one of his -- either time, remember the press asked about the military, he'll tell them. No, I'm not going to talk about that. He's had great success in it. And part of that is because before he got into office, President Obama really didn't listen to the generals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, except when they were on shows.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the rules of engagement.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And the rules of engagement. And so, I think this president is going to lead, this is one of the issues that people are going to remember him for is having a strong military.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But it only takes one thing, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Takes -- only one -- Terrorists only have to be good once.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, as we do this mission accomplished segment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm saying mission unaccomplished.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no. But wait a second, I thought you were the one. Every day, you say to me, hey, look at all these great things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . Trump has done. I believe your number one is defeated ISIS.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, but then when I read the newspapers, I see they say ISIS.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I said decimated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The inspector general, 28,000 in Syria and Iraq.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . right? And the Pentagon says they're well-positioned and growing. And I think, but, gee, Greg said that they've been defeated by.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've said they were decimated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's a difference.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Speaks to everyone's point here, too. You guys are absolutely right. And this is part of why we have a tactic and strategy that's working, which is the fact that the president pushed the decision making capabilities in the hands of the tactical and strategic commanders. And that's why, for example in Afghanistan, the strategy is surgical air strikes and counterintelligence. And it's working, and there're ebbs and flows and some weeks are better than others. And after 17 years, obviously, it's a bit exhausting. But members of the military referred to it as mowing the lawn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: They basically say we -- it's our constant presence and our efforts against the -- its counterterrorism efforts there. But we're supporting the Afghan government that we've helped in state, and to maintain that chaos between al Qaeda, ISIS, the Taliban, and the Afghan government. But the bottom line is, from what we have and what we have inherited, we absolutely are in the best position possible even in the face of good and bad weeks, and it's because of pushing that autonomy to the commanders.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So here's what I would say. Thank you, Obama. Thank you. And thank you, deep state.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Ronald Reagan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . is able to find -- because, remember.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's go way back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Weren't you going after Obama for using drones to attack.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, I've always been pro-drones. A pro-dromo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Intelligence sending intelligence and we do it in a way that is specific and targeted.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And we have been having success, and thank goodness we got this guy.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: But that was after the August campaign.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . to get through security.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That was after the August 2017 campaign. So this thing that you just cited that was after -- after President Trump took over. And that was his surge -- I mean, the surge occurred under President Obama, but this was a campaign, a targeted campaign, and that was the guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying -- but the strategy was basically Obama's strategy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's always Obama's.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Our allies are helping us as well, don't forget. Like the U.N. announces. But I would also say, you know, President Trump just announced today that he's canceling the 2.1 percent annual raise for federal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Federal workers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . employees. That includes those intel people that you're talking about that do all that work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Lawrence, respond to that as a libertarian.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't you dare.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All of them need to be cut.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Nope.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know. We'll see.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the president could say look how much better the economy is under my leadership.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Look at all these tax revenue coming into the treasury. I will now give this race because Obama starved you of these raises, and that's why federal employees, you should love me. Even if you don't, that's fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But here it is. We give a tax cut to the richest people in America. We refused to pay federal workers, including those who killed this man. How absurd.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They also have better health care than us, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. A major debate reignited over a report about the federal government's secret war on weed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The table is about to explode.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's the topic, is the White House about to wage a war on pot? According to a BuzzFeed report, the Trump administration is starting a committee to counter pro-marijuana messaging, 14 federal agencies working on collecting data showing the negative aspects of weed in an effort to try to balance what they think is an unbalanced public debate on the drug. But some activists, some Democratic lawmakers in states where recreational pot is now illegal, they're pushing back, calling it a misguided smear squad led by President Trump. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right. Here's my two biggest issues with this. The first is that the reconciliation between the states and federal approach it needs to be addressed. And right now there's too much confusion with law enforcement, especially, and with citizens. And, obviously, we have a bipartisan bill that has been introduced. It's making it was through the senate and I'm all for that. My second biggest issue is a waste of resources in the criminal justice system being spent pursuing this. Of drug offenders in the prison system about 10 percent are for cannabis, and their sentences are statistically the shortest, so think about how much we're wasting prosecuting, arresting, prosecuting, incarcerating these criminals. They're essentially low-level, nonviolent in that -- you know I'm not starting with the exceptions in that pot, no pun intended, to put them behind bars. And to me, the larger national conversation is, especially coming out with the White House is recent commitment to a criminal justice reform. It doesn't make sense with, A, this coming out and, B, kind of the -- as Senator Gardner said, putting the ketchup back in the bottle. It's a little bit too late for that. And I just think moving forward, nationally, that it would behoove us to be as efficient as possible and to realize, again, the amount of waste and abuse that's being spent pursuing what really is a -- it's a non-ripple effect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Lawrence, Emily makes the point, she says why is this a priority? Why is the White House putting energy and thought in 14 federal agencies on this case? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because the president wants him to.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, no. I don't think this is the president. I think this is Jeff Sessions. Jeff Sessions never stood on this issue. He hates weed. But if you're anti-opioid -- if you're anti-opioid, then you should be pro- marijuana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The picture behind your head.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like this is great, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: So.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're really a pothead.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The president is a practical person. He realizes that we shouldn't be spending money on this, prosecuting people on this. He realized he's pro-veteran. This has stopped the veteran and suicide in many of the states where it's been passed. He's anti-opioid. This prevents people from going to those addictions. So, the president is a logical person, but his attorney general is anti-criminal justice reform and anti-weed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The president is definitely all of those things. But also, if you listen to the president's speech, like he doesn't like drugs. He doesn't do them himself. He doesn't think it's a good idea. He thinks there's better ways.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, I don't think he drinks alcohol.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I think this whole committee thing, it wasn't just about, like, turning back all of those very progressive and smart things, especially for veterans in treating PTSD. It's about not having any counter programming to say that smoking marijuana it's not like taking a vitamin.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have to interject here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because I have six pages of notes to get through. All right. Just because you don't like something doesn't make it wrong. Number two, the White House does believe that the prevailing pro-marijuana narrative is too one-sided, but that's after 70 years of it being one-sided in the opposite direction. Do you remember the demon weed, it's a gateway drug. A lot of this stuff had no statistics to back it up. So what we're trying to do is to reach a reasonable midpoint where we are with alcohol, where we know that it offers benefits but it can be abused. You shouldn't be smoking pot in the morning. You treat it like a martini after work. Once you're successful so you're not a dirt bag. Everything -- everything with benefits that offers relief in life comes -- and alleviates suffering. Whether it's opioids or marijuana, it can be abused. But the state should not be involved in legislating your oblivion. As a human being, you have an individual right to ease your own suffering. It's a mistake. I do think -- I agree with you. This is more Sessions than Trump. I agree with you. I think -- and by the way, I don't see much evidence that the legalization has led to more violent behavior. Most of the violent behavior, the increases in the country are in Chicago and Baltimore, which is not about pot. It might be gang land drugs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or its about fentanyl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fentanyl. Or just drug warfare, which is based on illegal drugs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think -- I do think there are communities in the country, especially, like, where I went to college in Pueblo, Colorado, it's not been all sunshine and daisies out there when they moved forward on legalization.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It would be if you smoked.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Might be. Might be. I mean, I asked Lawrence in the break and he asked me not to ask him, but I'm going to ask him. Would you, like -- it's -- like, a little bit of counter programming is good. I understand the whole thing about 70 years of one way. And they're also finding, like, some really great benefits. But if you look at what taxpayers are having to pay for increased hospital stays.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We do that with alcohol. You know?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. So should we add another one?

utterances.speaker: JONES, GUEST
utterances.utterance: I don't think it's because of marijuana, either, why they're increasing the hospital stays.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not killing anybody. Marijuana is not killing the users.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You don't have overdoses of marijuana.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think you could find --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, it's not the overdoses.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think you can find a single overdose. Maybe viewers can find one. But I don't think there is -- I don't think there is a marijuana -- I don't think there's a marijuana overdose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Back me up.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: What deserves our attention to nationally, I think, is more the fentanyl pouring over the border.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Through especially the shipping system. And you know, our United States Postal Service has an exemption against full screening. China is literally flooding the country with fentanyl, and we are struggling to come up with overdose statistics.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Senator Rob Portman has a bill about this very thing, to try to prevent it, and it's moving forward in the Senate. And it actually might move forward in the House, as well, this fall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, I just wanted to conclude on this note. I think a lot of this is acting as if, oh, it's those young thugs out there who are doing marijuana. Let me tell you, the marijuana legalization, I think is being pushed by our seniors --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- by people who, you know what, just want to be able -- I'm just telling you. So I don't know where -- you think it's Sessions.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm worried that you're just attacking Sessions for Trump. Bu I don't know that the president --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, that's how he gets back at Sessions. Make him pass criminal justice reform. Make him cooperate with these local states, and I guarantee you, he'll resign by himself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that -- wow.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's how much he hates weed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. I think maybe you're having a smoky dream there. The Democratic governor of New York taking swipes at ICE and President Trump during a testy primary debate yesterday. Controversial remarks for you to hear straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's the new liberal litmus test. Democrats are replacing the battle of ideas with a competition to see who hates President Trump and his policies more. That's what happened during the tense face-off between New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and his opponent, Cynthia Nixon.

utterances.speaker: GOV. ANDREW CUOMO, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: Today you have to fight Donald Trump, who is the main risk to the state of New York.

utterances.speaker: CYNTHIA NIXON, D-NEW YORK GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I would say that Donald Trump did tweet at you about whether or not America was great, and you backed down pretty quickly. You stood up to him about as well as he stands up to Putin.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.utterance: On immigration, nobody has stood up to Donald Trump the way I have. New York state is the state that said, "We will not cooperate with ICE. They're a bunch of thugs."

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Wow. The showdown also getting downright nasty with personal attacks.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.utterance: My opponent lives in the world of fiction. I live in the world of fact. Let's just do a few facts. OK? The subway system is owned by New York City.

utterances.speaker: NIXON
utterances.utterance: The MCA has been controlled by the state since 1965.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.utterance: Can you -- can you stop interrupting? Can you stop interrupting?

utterances.speaker: NIXON
utterances.utterance: Can you stop lying?

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.utterance: Yes. As soon as you do.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Wow, a lot of craziness happened. Juan, I will throw this to you. It seems to me, as a former Obama supporter in 2008, that the Democrats had a message. And with him, it was hope and change and positivity, getting young people involved with the movement. But it seems now that the Democrats don't have a message, and they're trying to out-Trump Trump. So what is you guys' message?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I think there's a strong message talking about the midterms. But the thing that you are picking up on, I think you are right, is they compete in terms of their animosity towards Trump. And I think it's sad to say they imitate a lot of the Trump-type behavior. I remember Trump, at his debates would talk about Lying' Ted, Little Marco and Low Energy Jeb and all that. Remember that? And I think they might as well have said that: "Stop interrupting." "You stop lying." I mean, it's just -- you know, to me it's like schoolyard again, and it's, you know, Trumpian. I was hoping for a better debate, Lawrence. I thought this was not a great debate. This business about, you know, first of all, how hot was the room? I want to know. How hot was the room? But it seems to me that coming out of this, I thought Cynthia Nixon did a better job than I would have ever guessed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was surprised.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Emily, it didn't seem like the American people or New York residents got what they wanted in that debate. They didn't hear about what the candidates were typically for. Part of the whole Trump effect that I think people discount is that it's real; that's him. That's who we is as a person. And many of the other candidates in the Republican process that have tried to be like Trump and are -- that are inauthentic, it didn't work for them. Do you think it's going to work for the Democrats in this race?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I don't. And I hear what you're saying. And I think it's interesting that you brought that up, because as people are -- candidates are bringing up that strategy of who's more anti-Trump, but what happens to the voters if and when they get elected and then if their only status is resistance, how can we rely on them to get anything done when all know there has to be some type of balance bargaining once you assume office. And I think, when I watch the debate, I just felt like it was like when you put your dog in a rabbit costume for Halloween. It's like it's still a dog. It's not a rabbit. And that's how I feel about Governor Cuomo and these people who are these Democratic candidates who are being pushed more progressive because of their more progressive challengers. But in reality, they're just going to go right back. I mean, within two months of Cynthia Nixon declaring, Cuomo literally reversed public positions on recreational marijuana, and plastic bags in New York, and public housing, and restoring voter rights to felons, and on all of these issues, while at the same time threatening unions and community groups if they ever gave money to anyone supporting Nixon. "You're going to lose my number." It's like you're still the entrenched politician that these progressives are arguing against. So again, you're still just the dog. You're not the rabbit costume.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Dana, there was a lot of anti-ICE sentiment. And you know, even at campus reform, we reported on them at UC Berkeley telling kids to report to the police.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think they got the memo earlier this week there was that AP poll that said, like, only 21 percent of Democrats think that's a good idea. So I think they waste their time on that, but it does get them press coverage. I make a prediction here. I think this primary is going to be a lot closer than people think. I think that he gave her a chance to have a lot of headlines. The headlines for him were terrible. She got a ton of free airtime. Debates can move votes. If you think about how -- go back to New Hampshire of 2016, when Marco rubio and Christie went at it. And that absolutely hurt Marco Rubio in that debate. So it can make a difference. Cuomo looked thin-skinned. He looked very rusty. I'll tell you something else about her. Women have -- sometimes have a hard time when they're up against a man, because their voice drives people crazy. Her voice does not drive people crazy. They're used to it from television, and also, she's got a lower register. It's an important thing for her. And De Blasio [SIC] was able to go after Cuomo, and it was a very effective attack on the subway system. So watch. She might actually do better than you think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes -- go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was going to say, when you say drive crazy, you mean it's because -- when they have to raise their voice to get past the guys.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hillary Clinton, it like, drove people crazy. Sarah Palin. They would say, like, maybe she needs a voice coach, because it's hard when women get -- when you get animated, you tend to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Raise your --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- increase your octave.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was listening to Andrew Cuomo, and I was trying to figure out who's the smarter Cuomo brother. And that's like saying what is the squarest frisbee. But you know, two -- you saw two candidates out there. One, she was definitely better. No question. But two candidates were diminishing the importance of law and order, which is what Trump won on. So you had ICE being thugs, and then she made a comment about how law and order doesn't need as much input as other things. And I think it's because they have the luxury of the resurgence of law and order for the past three decades in New York City, which has dramatically reduced crime, made the place safer. So now that they've had the cure, they don't need to cure anymore. That's not how it works.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say before we close, you know, Gillum is upset in Florida against establishment Democrats. He was down double digits. And guess what? Octovio-Cortez [SIC], Alexandra, here in New York was down 35 points --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- to Joe Crawley. And guess what? Nixon is down 35 to Andrew Cuomo.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's definitely anybody's race.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The one thing is she was likable, and he wasn't.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's a good point. Up next --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Red Rover, Red Rover. Send Bobby right over.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Red Rover, Red Rover. Send Bobby right over.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Red Rover, Red Rover. Send Bobby right over.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Are kids games like Red Rover really too inappropriate for schools? A state's no-fun list is sparking outrage. Ahead.

utterances.speaker: ADAM SANDLER, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: Now you're all in big, big trouble.

utterances.speaker: DECICCIO
utterances.utterance: Outrage in Alabama after games that most of us grew up playing, like dodgeball, tag, and musical chairs, were told to be off-limits. The state's superintendent is now trying to calm down angry parents, saying it's up to public schools to decide their own physical education activities. OK, you guys. So apparently two years ago, the state of Alabama issued guidance and said that during physical education classes at these schools, you literally could not play tag and Red Rover and dodgeball and these fun, normal games. And some of the reasons cited were, you know, it makes people feel uncomfortable. They get hurt. They're left out, whatever. But the superintendent now came in, and he basically was like, "Look, this wasn't on my watch. You guys do you." So OK, here's my question. So Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- growing up on the peninsula, what was recess like for you? I feel like I can imagine you being a total maniac, and everyone taking you - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We were an unusual school. We had a fight club, where we'd pit one child against another child in a bare-knuckled cage match. And the one that survived could then have lunch. And they did it day after day. It was ugly. Only two kids made it out of that school. I think that they -- I think they should change dodgeball so that everybody gets a ball and, instead of throwing it at people, you just hug it in a dark room, listening to soft jazz.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wasn't that nice? Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Dana, what about you? What was your favorite recess activity in Colorado?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was thinking about this this morning.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You were getting high a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I was with the smokers. No, I wasn't. I was boring. No, not the smokers. Mom, no.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mom, I was not. OK --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Taking strange rides on planes?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you remember tetherball?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I loved tetherball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Tetherball was like -- and I liked it so much that my mom and dad put one in our backyard in Parker, Colorado, where we grew up. I also loved Foursquare.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Foursquare was great. Should have been an Olympic sport.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I also did love kickball. I was actually pretty good. I was pretty fast.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fast runner.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I can see that. Like zipping around.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: OK, so Lawrence, in Dallas, what was the scene like for you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There was a scene.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Describe it for us.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, we dominated in all sports, and so everyone is being prepared for the whole sports routine. But honestly, though, I think eliminating these activities is why the stress level for these kids are going up. They have no diversity.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Outlet.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They have no way to get rid of that. And maybe you fall down and you scratch your knee and all that, but you get back up and you go. But right now, everybody wants a participation trophy. Everybody wants to be, you know, coddled. And I think it's just destroying the next generation.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. So in Brooklyn, Juan, growing up, A, set the scene. And B, what changes do you see there? I know you love your grandkids. You talk about them a lot. What changes do you see between your recess activities and how you grew up and what they're engaged in now?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think I've ever been in their playground, because I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank God, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think things are more organized now, as we see by the -- what the Alabama school district was trying to do. Because you know, I liked dodgeball and, you know, Red Rover and all that stuff. I thought that was a whole lot of fun. But I do know that people got embarrassed, even humiliated. And once in a while, somebody would and up with a knot on their head, because they got hit in the wrong spot or fell on their face, et cetera. So you know, I guess -- I don't know if it's because we're a more litigious society, and the school district wants to protect itself. I don't know. But I don't think this is about kids being snowflakes today, because I --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In Brooklyn, kids would fight and kids still fight. I mean, that just goes on. I prefer, by the way, things like, you know, races, stickball. I mean, we used to play those games, too. What's wrong with that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing I loved, where those -- the bar --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Monkey bars.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Gymnastic bars, monkey bars, but also -- the ones that you climb across are the monkey bars, but just the solid one. Because I could do a daddy backflip -- no, a granddaddy backflip. Like, whatever. What is that called?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I literally was -- I can throw up just thinking about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It would give my mom a heart attack all the time. Because it was like, the bottom was just gravel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but you know what they have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The landing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, now they have -- the ground is this kind of rubbery Styrofoam. Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You like that, don't you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It does protect the kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I sleep in parks. I like that stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: DECICCIO
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have a new "I Hate These People."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're changing "One More Thing" up as we go along. It's time for "One More Thing" -- Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. So these are the dog days of summer. Baseball stadiums have bring your pup to the park day. What about these racetracks? Well, how about putting the dogs right on the race track? That's what happened at Minnesota, Canterbury Race Track. Watch these basset hounds go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Ready, set, go! One of the dogs was sleeping! All right. And they're off. And Douglas has got keen early speed! Here comes Charlie! Charlie is there! Maroney is there. And look out for Rufus!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness. The Bark in the Park championship, sponsored by the Star-Tribune newspaper, will resume on Labor Day. There will be a special battle of the breeds featuring basset hounds, corgis and wieners.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And wieners.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Top dogs from each championship battling the other to be crowned -- yes, you guessed it -- top dog.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I really want Jasper to do that. I think that he would excel wildly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He barely moves.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. My turn, lions and tigers and hyenas? Oh my. Look at this. A Beijing wildlife park put eight cubs including Siberian tigers, spotted hyenas and an African lion to nurse with a golden retriever alongside her own puppies after the cubs were abandoned by their own mothers. And visitors have been enchanted by watching the unlikely pack have a good time there, you know, get to know each other a little bit. It's a wonderful site, watching animals play and grow together, and you can see more of this on our Facebook page -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're cute when they're babies. They're horrible when they're adults. Hyenas? They're disgusting creatures. By the way it's time for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate these people!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This just came to me. I have allergies. So I sneezed, and Emily goes, "You don't do the arm crook thing!" No, I don't! Because this is an expensive jacket. Do you know how much this jacket cost? I'm not blowing snot into my forearm.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: You have germs. You don't sneeze into your hands and then --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Germs are underrated, Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Germs are for the immune system! I'm not going to ruin this jacket!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a generational thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, I'm not Count Dracula!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's a generational thing. Because you're younger a little bit. Right? And so then that's a new thing for, like, young people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not speaking to you anymore.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute. You hate Emily? Don't hate Emily.

utterances.speaker: DECICCIO
utterances.utterance: For my One More Thing, I want to shine the spotlight on a truly remarkable man, Special Agent Jeff James, United States Secret Service. Just retired this week after 22 years of serving with the Secret Service presidential detail. I've had the honor of calling him a longtime friend. It's my honor right now to direct appreciation for his exceptional, selfless and truly heroic service to our country and our presidents, regardless of party, regardless politics, for over two decades. He's protected George W. Bush, Donald Trump, Condoleezza Rice, numerous heads of state. And he's now come full circle. This is the best part. He was an English teacher before he joined the Secret Service 1996, and for his next chapter, he's been tapped by the Seneca Valley School District just north of Pittsburgh to be their head of security and safety.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, I know him well. Congratulations to you, and thank you for all your service -- Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Take us out.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Those audience members out there, you know that I love hip-hop. And I love it because of the capitalism message that's in it. Rapper T.I. is putting his own wealth fame to good use, spending millions of dollars of his own money to revitalize his neighborhood where he grew up. He's spending $2 million to build new businesses, low-income housing in his hometown in Atlanta.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's my brother T.I.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. That was a great show everyone. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." And then "Special Report" up next. Hey, Bret.
